pr_title: Use TabletFile for Tablet, Scans and compaction

timeline.bodyText:
When I looked at this code I found myself wondering if any follow on code relies on the metadata entry for the TabletFile created here.  If so that could result in a silent bug (where we try to delete something in the metadata table that does not exists).  This makes me think it would be nice to be able to construct a TabletFile w/o a metadata entry and anything trying to get the metadata path would get an exception.  This would cause things to fail fast.
Could possibly have a TabletFile constructor that only takes a path and when this constructor is used to create a the object, attempts to get the metadata entry result in an exception.
timeline.author: keith-turner

replies.bodyText: That is a good point.  The volume replacement code (which is where this is used) will delete the original file but I don't see where it will write out the new path.  Is this done during compaction?  If so, then we will have problems if we throw an exception since the string won't ever exist in the metadata.

This class is used by CompactionStrategy which is a pluggable component.  So this changes could break existing compaction strategy plugins.
I think this change is ok because with these types being outside of SPI, its hard to analyze in a rigorous way.   It would not surprise me if there were already other breaking changes.
timeline.author: keith-turner

timeline.message:
Use TabletFile for Tablet, Scans and compaction

* Made use of TabletFile from Ample through Tablet code, compactions
and scans where object represents a file in a Tablet
* Moved TabletFile to metadata package
* Added TabletFile constructor for the cases when switching volumes and
bulk import where we aren't reading a string from the metadata but have
to create a Path object to resolve the absolute path. That Path object
gets passed to TabletFile so multiple Paths don't need to be created
* Garbage collector will still use strings for delete candidates since
they can be a tablet directory
